body: OK, I won't notify you about version 4.x.x again, unless you re-open this PR.

Thanks, I just have one small nit regarding the logged message.

VOTE +1, pending change.

> What happens in the case where a query is sent to the server and the server needs more processing time than the idle connection timeout before sending back results? I think a test case might need to be added for this scenario.

@kenhuuu I added a change to address this - I changed SslCheckHandler to a generic 'channel closed' handler which detects if it closed due to idle timeout and then throws an appropriate error message. Added integration for this scenario as well.

Checked latest changes, my VOTE is still +1.
VOTE +1. Thanks for the change! If you could post the performance results/comparisons it would be great as well.

> VOTE +1. Thanks for the change! If you could post the performance results/comparisons it would be great as well.

Posted throughput results and profiler screenshots
To review, I would just take a look at the change made to the GraphSONMapper and just ensure that only the unnecessary types were removed at a high level.
Closing as https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/2860 contains newer changes that invalidate these results.

I scanned the changes for features I worked on in master-http (connection pooling, max response size, ssl error handling) and it looks good for those changes.
VOTE +1

I did a general scan and looked closer through parts involving changes I've made. There are some minor nits which looks like will be fixed in follow-up docs update, as commented by Ken, so I'm good with the changes. 

VOTE +1

thanks @xiazcy for the reply 
I have upgraded the dependency since it was vulnerable to one of the [High severity issue](https://security.snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JAVA-COMFASTERXMLJACKSONCORE-7569538).

Hi again, just checking in to see if you are able to add that test.

Based on information that I've recently read (which could be inaccurate), I think the `SO_KEEPALIVE` option and the `IdleTimeoutHandler` can be used together. TCP probes shouldn't be surfaced by `recv()` so it shouldn't reset the idle timer. If this can be confirmed (via a small test), then I think its probably OK to just add the `SO_KEEPALIVE` option regardless of whether the idle monitor is supported.

That being said, I'm still a bit skeptical about the real-world usefulness of this PR given that Netty can't control things like keepalive period and so on as those require OS-level options to be set. This just ends up using OS defaults which users may or may not find useful. So while I still support merging this PR, I think it will ultimately be replaced by the idle monitor.

Again, it would great if you could confirm that setting this option doesn't affect the idle monitor, in which case, you can just always have this option on.

Hi and thank you for contributing.

The `master` branch which is for 4.0 won't support WebSockets so your changes will need to target 3.7-dev instead. The code you are modifying now will be replaced with code that supports HTTP.

Have you noticed the same `unexpected-response` coming back from Gremlin Server?

Hi and thanks for contributing.

I was wondering what kind of testing you did for this PR. As noted earlier, it seems like this version was pinned for a reason. Have you looked into any potential issues with Spark/Scala if you change this Jackson version?

Sounds good, I'll open a new PR to target the correct branch and close this PR. We have noticed unexpected responses for 3 different situations on AWS Neptune so far. One was a random 400 error status code bug that AWS fixed. Another situation with AWS Neptune was using invalid AWS credentials. Third one we noticed recently is a throttling 500 status code. These situations were difficult to debug before we started reading the body when the web socket hit these unexpected responses.
New PR targeting the correct base branch opened here: https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/2936
